snippet: Nearly six in 10 people say the United States should not take a leading role in trying to solve conflicts, a New York Times/CBS News poll found.
abstract: New York Times/CBS News Poll finds that nearly 6 in 10 people say United States should not take leading role among all other countries in trying to solve conflicts overseas, but that reluctance does not extend to preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon; only about one-third say US should remain at the forefront.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and ALLISON KOPICKI
byline.contributor: Mark Landler reported from Washington, and Allison Kopicki from New York. Megan Thee-Brenan and Dalia Sussman contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Nearly six in 10 people say the United States should not take a leading role in trying to solve conflicts, a New York Times/CBS News poll found.

headline.seo: Americans Skeptical on Role in Foreign Conflicts, Poll Finds
headline.main: Skepticism Over U.S. Involvement in Foreign Conflicts
headline.print_headline: Skepticism Over U.S. Involvement in Foreign Conflicts
